Description: Body sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery open vessel, possibly a heavy chalice; white slip; interior: glazed black (only traces remaining); exterior: painted decoration consisting of head and shoulder of bearded man wearing spotted garment to right, possibly holding undetermined object in his hand in front of his face.
Curator's comments: Lemos describes the sherd as belonging to the Group with the Filling Ornament. The features typical for this group of vessels are the milky white slip and the use of filling ornament, which is found only in this group of sherds. The presence of filling ornament also suggests that the vases were mostly likely the earliest in the Grand Style. The male figures portrayed on vases from this group are perhaps the most expertly depicted and may all have been done by the same hand. Finally, the attempt at creating some perspective is rather clumsy. Though there is no evidence for filling ornament on this sherd, the depiction of male figures in this group is done in outline, as the male figure appears here. In later Grand Style vases male figures are depicted with coloured flesh.
Bibliographic references: Cook 1952 / A List of Clazomenian Pottery (p.166 note 41)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 110, p. 272, no. 701, pl. 92)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1638) (phase 2)
